A new Question and Answer was just added to the Physical Operations FAQ Page in the Return to Learn Hub. (https://www.framingham.k12.ma.us/Page/8905) Pasting in full below for easy access.

QUESTION: Can my child use their own chromebook vs. a school issued chromebook? (Updated 9/2/20)

ANSWER:While students are able to use their own personal devices to access remote learning, the District strongly recommends that all Framingham Public School students use school-issued chromebooks.

School issued chromebooks have a few features that have been added on to make them work better in our classrooms.

- They have protection against unauthorized and potentially harmful sites.
- They allow teachers to use a program called Securly which allows them to control each student's chromebook during class time. This is most often used in elementary and middle schools.
- The district’s technology staff can troubleshoot or replace technology that is not working.

“In the middle of this public health and economic crisis, we must focus on directing scarce financial resources towards the classrooms,” said Dr. Robert Tremblay, Superintendent of Framingham Public Schools “This one move will protect multiple educator positions from budget cuts. While it is uncomfortable, unfamiliar, and honestly unfathomable, we have done what none of us would have ever believed possible over the last few months. Even if we had years to prepare for the fully-remote operation that we now have in place, we never would have realized the same success had we not been driven to innovate out of necessity. This decision was not easily made as it will impact the working lives of more than 60 staff members who work at the Central Office, but it is the right decision to save school positions.”

Did you know the word origami itself is a compound of two smaller Japanese words: ori, meaning to fold, and kami, meaning paper? Mia Homann, an 8th grader at Cameron Middle School created these beautiful paper cranes as part of an Origami project for Tech Ed @ Home!

When asked about the project, Mia said, “...I made two paper cranes for today's assignment, a purple and yellow one. I was excited when I saw this assignment because Origami is an important traditional form of art on my mother's side of the family which is Japanese. She always teaches me how to create all kinds of animals and objects! What is fascinating about Origami is that all one needs is a square piece of paper, and nothing else. It makes the brain exercise how it can utilize that one sheet of paper to create beautiful works of art.”

It’s Census Day! The 2020 Census is here! The census is the foundation of our democracy, and it’s on all of us to ensure that everyone gets counted. The 2020 Census is more than a population count. It's an opportunity to shape the future of the Framingham community. Information gathered through Census results have an impact on planning and funding for health clinics and highways, fire departments and disaster response, education programs, political representation and so much more.
The U.S. Census counts every person in the country every 10 years. Residents should have recently received a letter from the U.S. Census Bureau with a unique code. The letter asks you to go online to respond to the 2020 Federal Census. Please be aware that the census asks for birth dates, but no other personal information (e.g. social security numbers) is requested.
The census is quick, easy, important and all of your answers are confidential.
Please visit www.my2020census.gov or dial 1-844-330-2020 with any questions and complete your census in order to be counted today.

Community Event Support!
Supporting Twice-Exceptional Learners at School and at Home
Students who have special needs and have high levels of ability are called Twice-exceptional or 2e. They are very often misunderstood because either they are seen only as special needs students, or their high level of ability masks their special needs. This webinar will help educators and parents understand this phenomenon better and find out what to do about it with their students in school and children at home.

Attend in person at Framingham State, or participate in the live webinar remotely. The session will also be recorded for later viewing.

Today Mrs. Maurao made rounds through several Stapleton classrooms, reading 'Ricky, the Rock that Couldn't Roll' by Jay Miletsky and illustrated by Erin Wozniak. This read-aloud activity was accompanied by lessons on morals, perseverance, and friendship. The kids were engaged and enjoyed having a special guest reader!

About the book: Get ready to meet a new rock group! From zippy, little pebbles to big strong boulders, the rocks (and their ladybug friend) get together to play and roll around their favorite hill, only to find that one of their friends, Ricky, can't roll with them. Unlike all of the others, who are all round, Ricky can't roll because he's flat on one side. Determined not to leave their friend behind, the rocks and the ladybug set out to help Ricky roll around - one way or another.

Pulled from Framingham Source: The Framingham High School Black Student Union is hosting a community screening of the movie Hidden Figures (2016) as a kick-off to Black History Month.

Mira Donaldson, FHS Student, said they are screening the film to showcase national figures that are not always highlighted in history, with talkback discussion afterward.

Hidden Figures is about a trio of “brilliant African-American women at NASA — Katherine Johnson (Taraji P. Henson), Dorothy Vaughan (Octavia Spencer) and Mary Jackson (Janelle Monáe) — serve as the brains behind one of the greatest operations in history: the launch of astronaut John Glenn (Glen Powell) into orbit, a stunning achievement that restored the nation’s confidence, turned around the Space Race and galvanized the world.”

The event is Friday, February 7 at 7 p.m. at Framingham High. Cost is $5 per person. Pizza, candy & popcorn will be provided.

“All are welcome to join in on an evening full of insight, fun, and food,” said Donaldson.

Countries represented included Vietnam, Brazil, Honduras, Spain, Japan, Tanzania, Canada, Ghana, Algeria, India, and several others.

Come listen to musicians Lerner & Moguilevsky - Artists-in-Residence – musicians from Argentina an evening for students, families, and neighbors to celebrate the multi-cultural nature of our community.
